pullRequest.body:
Some results are
- The ring Krull dimension and the topological dimension of the prime spectrum of a ring are the same
- A field is zero-dimensional and a PID that is not a field is one dimensional
- An Artinian ring is zero-dimensional
- The Krull dimension of ring $R$ is equal to the supremum of heights of maximal ideals [00KG](https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/00KG)
- two definitions of module length agree
- A module is finite length iff both artinian and noetherian
- length of module $M$ is equal to the sum of length of $N$ and length of $M / N$ where $N$ is a submodule of $M$.
- Noetherian ring has only finitely many minimal primes #9088
- In a zero dimensional ring, prime ideals are maximal
- Artinian rings has finitely many maximal ideals #9087
- zero-dimensional rings with finitely many prime ideals are products of its localizations: $R \cong \prod_{\mathfrak{p}}R_{\mathfrak{p}}$
- Let $M_0 \le ... \le M_n$, then $l(M_n/ M_0) = l(M_1/M_0) + l(M_2/M_1) + ... + l(M_n/M_{n-1})$ where $l$ denotes module length.
- If $f : R \to S$ is a ring homomorphism and $M$ an $S$-module, then $l_R(M) \le l_S(M)$, when $f$ is surjective then they are equal. (Note that this is expressed using `[Algebra R S]` and `RestrictScalars R S M`, instead of a literal ring hom)
- Artinian rings are noetherian ring of dimension 0.
- For 0-dimensional local ring, its maximal ideal is locally nilpotent
- In notherian ring, $I \le \sqrt{J}$ implies $I ^ n \le J$ for some $n$
---

nodes.body:
This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#6309~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->
There are some `simpNF` linter failure in `MeasureTheory` part of the library which is a bit strange.

Can you extract a TFAE lemma with the following:
+ `ringKrullDim R = 0`
+ for any two primes P â‰¤ Q we have P = Q
+ all primes are maximal
+ all primes are minimal primes
+ (maybe?) all maximal ideas are minimal primes

Hmm, maybe not. I think the principle should be that we should give constructors of ringKrullDim = 0 requiring weakest possible conditions, but state strongest possible consequences under the ringKrullDim = 0 assumption. Under this principle, we should give constructors from:
+ all maximal ideals are minimal primes
+ all minimal primes are maximal among the primes
(both are weaker than "for any two primes P â‰¤ Q we have P = Q")

Given ringKrullDim = 0, the strongest consequences are:
+ for any two primes P â‰¤ Q we have P = Q
+ for any ideal, being prime is equivalent to being maximal, and equivalent to being a minimal prime

Oh apparently it's also equivalent to the prime spectrum being a [T1Space](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Separation.html#T1Space) (all primes are maximal so all points are closed), and we have [discrete_of_t1_of_finite](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Topology/Separation.html#discrete_of_t1_of_finite)

Actually, [Stacks](https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/04MG) has more equivalent conditions.
Your advice is great! We can use this to prove every 0-dimensional ring is isomorphic to product of all its prime localizations. Thanks!

Can you state this for arbitrary OrderIso between (Jordan-Holder) Lattices, not just Submodule? Because we already know that a LinearEquiv induces an OrderIso: [Submodule.orderIsoMapComap](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Module/Submodule/Map.html#Submodule.orderIsoMapComap).
We should probably define `CompositionSeries A â‰ƒ CompositionSeries B` given an OrderIso between A and B.

I feel that we should define FiniteLength for any JordanHolderLattice, and we should be able to show a lattice is finite length iff both < and > are well-founded. Also I think most of the places there's no reason to assume R to be commutative.

Good point! I will try to generalize finite length to all jordan holder lattices! Thanks for the suggestions.

It is probably also true that we can get pass by assume M is `AddCommMonoid` and R `semiring` even.

Here I have a general version of the fact that WellFoundedLT + WellFoundedGT implies the existence of a composition series: https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17478/files#diff-1d6e9102ebec04f1d702ffef68445fa574ac5c8b80c9a9e9c577c6b47a5e6625R236-R238

You're using Jordan--Hoelder (that all composition series have the same length) in this proof, but it's not actually necessary: since a finite length module is a (finite) iterated extensions of simple modules, what you need is just that simple modules are noetherian/artinian and that noetherian/artinian-ness is closed under extensions. This is done [here](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/17478/files#diff-b3215bbbbec31e2687f1ba2bc6f76d6b9dc8ed8b23256275de14e51e925f67a2R45-R47).
